thread.title: Why do our eyes feel swollen when we get tired?
thread.title_full: Why do our eyes feel swollen when we get tired?

author: The Pull List
title: Why do our eyes feel swollen when we get tired?
text:
Today's question:
Why do our eyes feel like they are swelling up when we get tired? What purpose would it serve, other than a mother knowing for sure it is nap time all the while the child denies being tired? When laying down it makes sense that fluids are pooling, but when one is upright, what is the purpose or mechanism?
Do you know what histoplasmosis is? Or angioedema?
Histoplasmosis is a fungal infection of the lungs that causes muscle aches, fever, chest pain, cough and more. Angioedema is swelling under the skin that often appears around the eyes and lips.
They are not only hard to spell, but also two of roughly 100 problems that can give you puffy peepers. Of course, puffy eyes are most frequently caused by fatigue, before or after sleeping.
Your eyes get puffy because of water retention. There is a lot space, as these things go, under your eyes
Puffy eyes usually occur due to tiredness after sleeping, but they can be caused by fatigue before and after sleep. Your eyes get puffy because of water retention. There is a fair amount of space under your eyes, and that's the first place many of us retain water. As you get older it becomes more common because your once-firm flesh loses elasticity so there is more space for water.
The puffiness usually gets worse while you are sleeping, especially if you sleep on your stomach.
Too much salt in your diet can make you retain water and puffiness also can be genetic.
As to why, the purpose –— I suppose it's like any other ache or pain. It tells you something is wrong.
